title: Why does AI Hallucinate?
snippet:
Why does AI Hallucinate?
We’ve all experienced this by now. We ask ChatGPT to generate some Swift code, especially using a new framework we haven’t worked with before, and it gives back legitimate-loo...
content:
Why does AI Hallucinate?
We’ve all experienced this by now. We ask ChatGPT to generate some Swift code, especially using a new framework we haven’t worked with before, and it gives back legitimate-looking code. But when we copy and paste the code into our codebase, the function it came up with doesn’t actually exist!
Swift code is just an example, but this can happen for anything. One time, for example, I was planning a road trip and it gave me an amazing destination I was really excited to go to only to find out it’s been closed for years when I looked into booking accommodations.
This phenomenon of AI generating false or misleading information is called Hallucinations. The biggest problem with this is that the AI doesn’t tell you when it’s telling the truth or not. It’s just as confident hallucinating as it is telling legitimate real-world information. So why does this happen?
To understand this, we need to understand how Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT work under-the-hood.

title: What are Tokens?
snippet:
What are Tokens?
A Large Language Model (LLM) processes text in “tokens”, not characters or words. For example, If you’re interested in using an API like OpenAI to integrate AI functionality into your...
content:
What are Tokens?
A Large Language Model (LLM) processes text in “tokens”, not characters or words. For example, If you’re interested in using an API like OpenAI to integrate AI functionality into your app, you will see that the pricing is based on tokens. For example, here is OpenAI’s pricing model for using GPT-4 Turbo:
See OpenAI Pricing here

You may have also seen AI-related tweets / blog / news about tokens:
Source Tweet

So what exactly are tokens? This is critical to know and understand not just as a terminology and understanding pricing, but for also understanding why certain bugs happen in AI systems.
The best person I’ve seen explain it very very well is an OpenAI founding team member Andrej Karpathy in his video Let's build the GPT Tokenizer. As the video is over 2 hours long, I’ll be summarizing from it here for easy reference. However, I do highly recommend for everyone to watch it…
The Goal
It is much easier to understand tokens if we understand the goal of using tokens.

title: Understanding Large Language Models: Completions vs Chat and Chat Completions
snippet:
Understanding Large Language Models: Completions vs Chat and Chat Completions
Before OpenAI had their big breakout with ChatGPT, they had a Large Language Model (LLM) product and API called “Completio...
content:
Understanding Large Language Models: Completions vs Chat and Chat Completions
Before OpenAI had their big breakout with ChatGPT, they had a Large Language Model (LLM) product and API called “Completions”. The Completions product did exactly what it sounds like. It completed any input. You can still find it and play with it in the OpenAI’s Playground portal:
Here, I simply input “A poem about spring” and it auto-completed the rest of my text with a poem about spring in green.

Most of us are very used to Google’s autocomplete in search results, but what makes this LLM autocomplete so impressive is that it can keep going beyond just a few words. For example, the above screenshot only captures 3 out of 9 full paragraphs it output for me based on my very small input of “A poem about spring”.
If you select the “Full spectrum” in the “Show probabilities” option at the very bottom of the OpenAI’s Playground menu on the right hand side and put in the same prompt, you will see how the LLM model

title: Taming Verbose LLMs: A Guide to Generating Direct Answers
snippet:
Taming Verbose LLMs: A Guide to Generating Direct Answers
Large Language Models (LLMs) in their current form are notorious for being too verbose… For example, when I ask Claude a direct question - suc...
content:
Taming Verbose LLMs: A Guide to Generating Direct Answers
Large Language Models (LLMs) in their current form are notorious for being too verbose… For example, when I ask Claude a direct question - such as “Who was the first US president”, I get this full response instead of the simple “George Washington” answer I was expecting.

This presents a problem for us as developers. We might want to use an LLM for direct responses such as “George Washington” but instead have to work around these big long verbose responses. In this post, we will use one such workaround using the example of an app for generating Swift code in response to a user request:

As seen in the screenshot - the goal is to generating ONLY SWIFT CODE and none of the verbosity around it that is usually present in Claude as seen in this response for the same query:

So how do we approach this?
The first step is to write the system and user prompt with the basic instructions. You can check the LLMManager in the Swift Code Gene

title: Prompt Engineering: Beyond the Hype!
snippet:
Prompt Engineering: Beyond the Hype!
One of the funniest things I find as I’m learning how to work with AI APIs is how important it is to be good at creative writing! If I had a big AI company with lo...
content:
Prompt Engineering: Beyond the Hype!
One of the funniest things I find as I’m learning how to work with AI APIs is how important it is to be good at creative writing! If I had a big AI company with lots of funding, I would for sure be hiring some English / Philosophy majors right now!
Unfortunately, some super sketchy marketing people have started calling themselves “Prompt Engineers”. So just that term gives us the cringe feeling. But it is incredibly important and must-know for working with AIs.
While, as developers, we’re used to working with APIs where we can give very specific parameters, with AI, the interaction is done in natural language. This is much more difficult as there could be many ways and many techniques for getting the results you need. And it could be extremely confusing. As this is something that is extremely new to me, I want to thank @vatsal_manot for teaching what I’ll be sharing in this post.
Thinking in Tokens
But first… before understanding Prompt Engineering,

title: Join Preternatural AI x Swift Workshops
snippet:
Join Preternatural AI x Swift Workshops
At Preternatural, we are working on building exhaustive client-side AI infrastructure for Swift, driven by our mission to empower Apple developers with a specia...
content:
Join Preternatural AI x Swift Workshops
At Preternatural, we are working on building exhaustive client-side AI infrastructure for Swift, driven by our mission to empower Apple developers with a specialized AI toolset. We believe that Apple developers are in a special position to solve previously insurmountable consumer challenges through innovative, AI-integrated user experiences.
As part of our commitment to the Apple developer community, we're excited to announce the launch of our Preternatural AI x Swift workshop series. These workshops are designed to bridge the gap between cutting-edge AI technologies and practical Swift development, enabling developers to create more intelligent, responsive, and user-centric applications.
Our workshops will cover a range of topics, from basic AI integration to advanced techniques, all tailored specifically for the Swift ecosystem. By providing hands-on experience and expert guidance, we aim to accelerate the adoption of AI technologies in iOS, ma

title: Hello, Preternatural!
snippet:
Hello, Preternatural!
You may know me as NatashaTheRobot from my previous blog and newsletter about Swift and Apple Development, my try! Swift conferences around the world, and more. And now I’m excit...
content:
Hello, Preternatural!
You may know me as NatashaTheRobot from my previous blog and newsletter about Swift and Apple Development, my try! Swift conferences around the world, and more. And now I’m excited to bring AI into this mix…
I’ve been fascinating with AI as soon as it “came out”. Of course AI has been part of computer science for decades, but I mean that magical point in time when OpenAI released their breakthrough ChatGPT product that made AI extremely applicable and accessible for everyday use.
As a developer, I immediately wanted to learn and understand it, and more importantly, I saw amazing use-cases for AI in building apps. More specifically, I’ve been studying the Sanskrit language in India for the past few years, and there is an incredible opportunity to use AI to make ancient Sanskrit texts much more accessible for those like me who want to learn. This is just one example. AI just opens up so many opportunities that haven’t been possible before without extreme amounts of

title: Building an AI-powered Poem Generator in Swift
snippet:
Building an AI-powered Poem Generator in Swift
Before Large Language Models (LLMs) became so widely used in the outbreak ChatGPT product, they were actually tested as super powerful completion machine...
content:
Building an AI-powered Poem Generator in Swift
Before Large Language Models (LLMs) became so widely used in the outbreak ChatGPT product, they were actually tested as super powerful completion machines. Based on just a simple prompt such as “And the cow jumped over the moon” for example, the LLM could complete it into a full original poem following in the pattern of the famous "Hey, diddle, diddle," nursery rhyme by Mother Goose. It achieves this by generating the next most likely word (or "token" to be more precise) based on all the training data it has processed, which can be as vast as the entire internet.
However, the LLM’s standalone completion functionality by itself was not found as usable in that state. Instead, OpenAI trained a new model (a brilliant move, in retrospect) with the help of thousands of overseas human workers to apply the completion functionality of the LLM in a User-Assistant conversation format. This chat interface became the breakout product of LLMs.
Knowing t

content: Master foundational architectural patterns, tool integration, and hands-on implementation with popular libraries and practical considerations for agentic AI development.
author: Maternus Herold

title: Model Misspecification in Simulation-Based Inference - Recent Advances and Open Challenges
snippet: Model misspecification is a critical challenge in simulation-based inference (SBI), particularly in neural SBI, where methods rely on simulated data to train neural networks. These methods often assum...
content: Model misspecification is a critical challenge in simulation-based inference (SBI), particularly in neural SBI, where methods rely on simulated data to train neural networks. These methods often assume that simulators accurately represent the true data-generating process, but in practice, this assumption is frequently violated. Such discrepancies can result in observed data that are out-of-distribution relative to the simulations, leading to biased posterior distributions and unreliable inferences. This blog reviews recent work on model misspecification in SBI, discussing its definitions, methods for detection and mitigation, and open challenges. The aim is to emphasize the importance of developing robust SBI methods that can accommodate the complexities of real-world applications.
author: Jan Teusen

title: Towards a statistical theory of data selection under weak supervision
snippet: Pulkit Tandon, research engineer at Granica, will present his work on data selection, showing how using surrogate models to select subsamples of a data set for labeling can improve training efficiency...
content: Pulkit Tandon, research engineer at Granica, will present his work on data selection, showing how using surrogate models to select subsamples of a data set for labeling can improve training efficiency and performance.
author: Pulkit Tandon

title: Introduction to Reduced Order Modeling
snippet: Sridhar Chellappa will introduce the concept of reduced order modeling (ROM), a technique used in the field of simulation and AI to reduce the complexity of mathematical models. The seminar will cover...
content: Sridhar Chellappa will introduce the concept of reduced order modeling (ROM), a technique used in the field of simulation and AI to reduce the complexity of mathematical models. The seminar will cover the basics of ROM, its applications, and a lead up to more ML-flavoured approaches.
author: Sridhar Chellappa

title: Recent Advancements in Tractable Probabilistic Inference
snippet: Antonio Vergari will give an overview about recent advancements in tractable probabilistic inference.
content: Antonio Vergari will give an overview about recent advancements in tractable probabilistic inference.
author: Antonio Vergari

title: Generalized Stability Guaranteed Quadratic Embeddings for Nonlinear Dynamical Systems
snippet: Pawan Goyal, Senior AI Engineer at appliedAI, will present a recent work in physics-enhanced machine learning on generalized quadratic embeddings for nonlinear dynamics.
content: Pawan Goyal, Senior AI Engineer at appliedAI, will present a recent work in physics-enhanced machine learning on generalized quadratic embeddings for nonlinear dynamics.
author: Pawan Goyal

title: optimagic: unifying the numerical optimization ecosystem in Python
snippet: optimagic is a Python package for numerical optimization. It is a unified interface to optimizers from SciPy, NlOpt and other packages. optimagic’s minimize function works ...
content: optimagic is a Python package for numerical optimization. It is a unified interface to optimizers from SciPy, NlOpt and other packages. optimagic’s minimize function works just like SciPy’s, so you don’t have to adjust your code. You simply get more optimizers for free. On top you get diagnostic tools, parallel numerical derivatives and more.
author: Tim Mensinger

title: Stochastic Optimal Control Matching
snippet: Carles Domingo-Enrich will present his work on Stochastic Optimal Control Matching (SOCM), a novel Iterative Diffusion Optimization (IDO) technique for stochastic optimal control that stems from the s...
content: Carles Domingo-Enrich will present his work on Stochastic Optimal Control Matching (SOCM), a novel Iterative Diffusion Optimization (IDO) technique for stochastic optimal control that stems from the same philosophy as the conditional score matching loss for diffusion models.
author: Carles Domingo-Enrich

title: From Theory to Practice: Neural Operators Transforming Acoustics
snippet: Jakob Wagner, Junior AI Researcher at the appliedAI Institute for Europe, will talk about the topic of his Master’s thesis, conducted in collaboration with TUM, on applying neural operators to r...
content: Jakob Wagner, Junior AI Researcher at the appliedAI Institute for Europe, will talk about the topic of his Master’s thesis, conducted in collaboration with TUM, on applying neural operators to real-world acoustic problems.
author: Jakob Wagner

title: CLP-Transfer: Cross-Lingual and Progressive Transfer Learning
snippet: The CLP-Transfer method introduces a novel approach for cross-lingual language transfer by leveraging token overlap and a small pre-trained model with the desired tokenizer, simplifying the transfer p...
content: The CLP-Transfer method introduces a novel approach for cross-lingual language transfer by leveraging token overlap and a small pre-trained model with the desired tokenizer, simplifying the transfer process without the need for fastText embeddings or bilingual dictionaries. Despite its practical advantages, the method’s performance on downstream tasks is limited, highlighting areas for future research and evaluation.
author: Anes Benmerzoug

title: Mesh-Independent Operator Learning for Partial Differential Equations
snippet: The mesh-independent neural operator (MINO) is a fully attentional architecture for operator learning that allows to represent the discretized system as a set-valued data without a prior structure.
content: The mesh-independent neural operator (MINO) is a fully attentional architecture for operator learning that allows to represent the discretized system as a set-valued data without a prior structure.
author: Samuel Burbulla

title: Symmetry Teleportation for Accelerated Optimization
snippet: A novel approach, symmetry teleportation, enhances convergence speed in gradient-based optimization by allowing parameters to traverse large distances on the loss level set by exploiting symmetries in...
content: A novel approach, symmetry teleportation, enhances convergence speed in gradient-based optimization by allowing parameters to traverse large distances on the loss level set by exploiting symmetries in the loss landscape.
author: Kristof Schröder

title: All-in-One Simulation-Based Inference
snippet: This paper presents a new SBI algorithm that utilizes transformer architectures and score-based diffusion models. Unlike traditional approaches, it can estimate the posterior, the likelihood, and othe...
content: This paper presents a new SBI algorithm that utilizes transformer architectures and score-based diffusion models. Unlike traditional approaches, it can estimate the posterior, the likelihood, and other arbitrary conditionals once trained. It also handles missing data, leverages known dependencies in the simulator, and performs well on common benchmarks.
author: Jan Teusen

title: Unravelling complexity in neuronal time-series data with BunDLe-Net
snippet: Akshey Kumar, postdoctoral member of the Neuroinformatics research group at TU Vienna, will talk about BunDLe-Net, a manifold-learning algorithm that effectively preserves relevant information while a...
content: Akshey Kumar, postdoctoral member of the Neuroinformatics research group at TU Vienna, will talk about BunDLe-Net, a manifold-learning algorithm that effectively preserves relevant information while abstracting away details that are irrelevant to the dynamics of a specific target variable.
author: Akshey Kumar

title: Position: Leverage Foundational Models for Black-Box Optimization
snippet: This paper explores the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) to address challenges in Black Box Optimization (BBO), particularly multi-modality and task generalization. The authors propose framing BBO ...
content: This paper explores the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) to address challenges in Black Box Optimization (BBO), particularly multi-modality and task generalization. The authors propose framing BBO around sequence-based foundation models, leveraging LLMs’ capabilities to retrieve information from various modalities resulting in superior optimization strategies.
author: Jan Teusen

title: Inducing Point Operator Transformer: A Flexible and Scalable Architecture for Solving PDEs
snippet: Seungjun Lee will talk about an attention-based neural operator architecture called an Inducing Point Operator Transformer (IPOT), which addresses the challenges of flexibility in handling irregular a...
content: Seungjun Lee will talk about an attention-based neural operator architecture called an Inducing Point Operator Transformer (IPOT), which addresses the challenges of flexibility in handling irregular and arbitrary input and output formats and scalability to large discretizations when solving partial differential equations (PDEs).
author: Seungjun Lee

title: WECHSEL: Cross-Lingual Transfer
snippet: Language transfer enables the use of language models trained in one or more languages to initialize a new language model in another language. WECHSEL is a cross-lingual language transfer method that e...
content: Language transfer enables the use of language models trained in one or more languages to initialize a new language model in another language. WECHSEL is a cross-lingual language transfer method that efficiently initializes the embedding parameters of a language model in a target language using the embedding parameters from an existing model in a source language, facilitating more efficient training in the new language.
author: Anes Benmerzoug

title: Deep neural operators as accurate surrogates for shape optimization
snippet: Deep neural operators, such as DeepONet, have changed the paradigm in high-dimensional nonlinear regression, promising significant generalization and speed-up in computational engineering applications...
content: Deep neural operators, such as DeepONet, have changed the paradigm in high-dimensional nonlinear regression, promising significant generalization and speed-up in computational engineering applications. In a recent paper, the authors investigate the use of DeepONet to infer flow fields around unseen airfoils with the aim of shape constrained optimization, an important design problem in aerodynamics that typically taxes computational resources heavily.
author: Samuel Burbulla

title: Dense Rewards and Continual RL for Task-Oriented Dialogue Policies
snippet: Christian will present a proposal for dense rewards in task-oriented dialogue systems to enhance sample efficiency and discuss continual reinforcement learning of dialogue policies. Key topics include...
content: Christian will present a proposal for dense rewards in task-oriented dialogue systems to enhance sample efficiency and discuss continual reinforcement learning of dialogue policies. Key topics include an architecture for continual learning, an extended learning environment, lifetime return optimization, and meta-reinforcement learning for hyperparameter adaptation.
author: Christian Geishauser

title: Interpreting CLIP's Image Representation via Text-based Decomposition
snippet: Interpreting the output of neural networks is often challenging because it entails putting into words patterns that may not be easily expressible in human language. This often results in forced explan...
content: Interpreting the output of neural networks is often challenging because it entails putting into words patterns that may not be easily expressible in human language. This often results in forced explanations that do not reflect the true decision-making process of the model. However, for CLIP-ViT models there is a natural way to map image features of each component of the Transformer network to text-based concepts.
author: Fabio Peruzzo

title: Scientific Inference With Interpretable Machine Learning
snippet: Timo will introduce a framework for designing interpretable machine learning methods for science, termed “property descriptors”.
content: Timo will introduce a framework for designing interpretable machine learning methods for science, termed “property descriptors”.
author: Timo Freiesleben

title: Amortized Bayesian Decision-Making for Simulation-Based Models
snippet: Bayesian inference is a popular tool for parameter estimation. However, the posterior distribution might not be sufficient for decision-making. Bayesian Amortized Decision-Making is a method that lear...
content: Bayesian inference is a popular tool for parameter estimation. However, the posterior distribution might not be sufficient for decision-making. Bayesian Amortized Decision-Making is a method that learns the cost of data and action pairs to make Bayes-optimal decisions.
author: Maternus Herold

title: LAVA: Data Valuation Without Pre-Specified Learning Algorithms
snippet: Today’s talk is about LAVA, an Optimal-Transport-based approach to data valuation that dispenses with training of a model to compute values.
content: Today’s talk is about LAVA, an Optimal-Transport-based approach to data valuation that dispenses with training of a model to compute values.
author: Feiyang Kang

title: RAGAR, Your Falsehood RADAR: RAG-Augmented Reasoning for Political Fact-Checking using Multimodal Large Language Models
snippet: Mohammed Abdul Khaliq, MSc. Computational Linguistics Programm at the Institute for Natural Language Processing of the University of Stuttgart, will give a talk on the topic of his Master’s thes...
content: Mohammed Abdul Khaliq, MSc. Computational Linguistics Programm at the Institute for Natural Language Processing of the University of Stuttgart, will give a talk on the topic of his Master’s thesis: “RAGAR, Your Falsehood RADAR: RAG-Augmented Reasoning for Political Fact-Checking using Multimodal Large Language Models”.
author: Mohammed Abdul Khaliq

title: sbi: the simulation-based inference toolkit
snippet: sbi is a Python package for Bayesian parameter inference on simulators. It implements state-of-the-art algorithms and comes with comprehensive documentation and tutorials, making it suitable for SBI p...
content: sbi is a Python package for Bayesian parameter inference on simulators. It implements state-of-the-art algorithms and comes with comprehensive documentation and tutorials, making it suitable for SBI practitioners. Additionally, it offers low-level modularity for researchers who wish to explore more advanced aspects of SBI.
author: Faried Abu Zaid

author: Maternus Herold

snippet: Álvaro Tejero-Cantero, group leader at the ml ⇌ science colab (University of Tübingen), will present PSI-KT, a hierarchical generative approach for estimating a lear...
content: Álvaro Tejero-Cantero, group leader at the ml ⇌ science colab (University of Tübingen), will present PSI-KT, a hierarchical generative approach for estimating a learner’s progress, spotlight at ICLR 2024.

title: Variance Reduced Shapley Value Estimation for Trustworthy Data Valuation
snippet: VRDS, an effective method to reduce the variance of Data Shapley, based on a stratified sampling technique with precomputed coefficients.

title: Conditional Flow Matching: Simulation-Free Dynamic Optimal Transport
snippet: Alex Tong, postdoctoral fellow at MILA (Université de Montréal), will talk about conditional flow matching, a family of simulation-free training objectives for continuous normalizing flows.
